Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Development Of Pastoral Based Subsistence Economies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Anthropological studies from different regions of the world have emphasized that the adoption of pastoralism is important in the development of communities relying on multiple subsistence systems. Several archaeological studies have indicated that pastoralism, in conjunction with hunter-gatherer-fisher strategies, persisted for several millennia. Thus, a detailed investigation of the role that early pastoralist orientations played within traditional hunter-gatherer-fisher subsistence systems contributes importantly to anthropological studies on the origins of multi-resource pastoralism and the part this played in broader social, cultural and political complexity. Within this broader context, and under the supervision of Dr. Bryan Hanks of the University of Pittsburgh, doctoral candidate Chuenyan Ng will investigate multi-resource pastoralism strategies used by late prehistoric steppe communities at the Bronze Age settlement of Stepnoye (2100-1500 BC) located in the Southeastern Urals region of Russia. The long-standing subsistence model for these communities has been defined as a sedentary agro-pastoral strategy with dominant use of livestock. However, based on recent studies, the nature and variability of the subsistence economy, especially wild plant resource exploitation for both human and livestock, are not well understood. Within sedentary pastoral communities the relationship between increasing livestock productivity and decreasing risk associated with resource sustainability is a continuous process. It is achieved only through control of land for grazing, regulations of the composition and size of herds, and the establishment of seasonal herding strategies including foddering. Did multi-resource pastoralism and catchment resource sustainability influence the development of these communities? To address this question, this project will develop a new model for local human-environmental relationships to better understand multi-resource pastoralism as an important economic component of these communities. . A broader contribution of the research is reflected in the important and productive collaborative relationships that have been developed with Russian institutions, faculty and students.

This project will undertake a systematic archaeobotanical and phytogeographical study of subsistence patterns among late prehistoric pastoralist communities. The multi-disciplinary approach draws productively from ethnographic, anthropological, and archaeological evidence, to examine relationships between ancient settlements, local site catchments, and the emergence of new forms of livestock herding that integrated with earlier traditions of hunting, gathering and fishing. A combination of detailed macro-botanical study, experimental archaeology, and computer simulation modeling through Geographic Information System software will produce a new model for understanding early traditions of multi-resource pastoralism. This research will contribute importantly to regional studies of the Sintashta culture and provide an important comparative case study for understanding key transitions among sedentary pastoralist societies with multi-resource subsistence economiesThis project will establish a detailed archaeobotanical database and computer simulation socio-ecnomic model that will provide a crucial foundation for future studies of late prehistoric subsistence patterns and pastoralist lifeways in the Eurasian steppes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation project investigated multi-resource pastoralism strategies used by late prehistoric steppe communities at two Bronze Age settlements (2100-1500 BCE) located in the Ui River valley of the Southeastern Ural Mountains region of the Russian Federation. The intellectual merits of this project can be seen in the multi-disciplinary approach that drew productively from ethnographic, anthropological and archaeological evidence. This research examined relationships between ancient settlements, local site catchments, and the emergence of new forms of livestock herding that integrated with earlier traditions of hunting, gathering and fishing. A combination of detailed macro-botanical study, experimental archaeology, and ethnographic research has produced a new model for understanding early traditions of multi-resource pastoralism in this region of the Eurasian steppes. A total of 180 soil samples were floated and analyzed from 3,700 liters of soil representing occupation sequences from the Middle Bronze Age to the Late Bronze Age (2100-1500 BCE). From these samples, 281 liters of charcoal and 2,300 pieces of plant remains (mainly seeds) were identified. A phytogeographical survey was completed that covered approximately 200 sq. km and identified over 50 types of local plant species. Ten local Russian families from three villages located in the Ui Valley were interviewed through ethnographic study about their annual/seasonal herding practices and use of local plant resources and winter fodder. A total of 60 dung/hay samples were collected for burning experiments in order to examine the remains of macro-botanical evidence. Harvest experiments were carried out in 10 locations to estimate the output of different vegetation zones. These collected data contribute importantly to regional studies of the Bronze Age Sintashta culture and provide an important comparative case study for understanding key transitions among sedentary pastoralist societies with multi-resource subsistence economies. The results from this project yielded the following conclusions from the data: (1) A strong correlation between wild plant species exploitation and the development of Sintashta communities during the Bronze Age, (2) plant exploitation behaviors that were well-organized seasonally and had localized patterns that did not include the use of domesticated plants, (3) herding patterns that were related to the distribution of certain types of plant species that were within distinct catchment vegetation zones.The results from this project provide essential new data in which to better understand socio-economicorganization of Sintashta societies in the Middle Bronze Age. Research undertaken in the Ui River valley has indicated an ancient pastoralist community with profound knowledge of local plant resources drawing on surrounding vegetation zones for subsistence requirements. Wild plant exploitation patterns in the Ui River valley remained consistent from the Middle Bronze Age to the Late Bronze Age (2100-1500 BCE) based on macrobotanical analyzes from Bronze Age settlement sites. 

The broader contributions of this research are reflectedin the important and productive collaborative relationships that were developed with Russian institutions, faculty and students and the multi-disciplinary nature of the research program. This project has produced a detailed archaeobotanical study in a region where such research is only just becoming more integrated within the field of archaeology. The archaeobotanical samples and comparative plant samples generated from this project are curated in Russia and a digitized database has been created that will support future research in this region. This project has formed the foundation of the Co-PI’s doctoral dissertation research.
